/audile-technique.title: audile technique
/audile-technique.content:
# audile technique

A concept from *!Jonathan Sterne* (as cited in *@BlueV2017*) which describes the practices of listening based in science and reason, encouraging that what is heard be rationalized.

Audile technique encouraged listening be directed towards private space and property, making it possible to marker *sound as a commodity*.

/commodified-anger.title: commodified anger
/commodified-anger.content:
# commodified anger

A form of anger which is projected on to the Black body, as *the Black body stands as site of excess and lack of affect* (*@Palmer2017*). This ignores the actual feelings of the Black person, which Palmer names imploding angerâ€”which is always interiorized and can only lead to loneliness.

*@Rankine2014* explores how [commodified anger](commodified%20anger.md) can cause actual Black anger. Adding to Palmer's notion of anger leading to loneliness, Rankine argues it always leads to disappointment, and is ultimately connected to the failings of*visibility politics*.

 > 
 > You begin to think, maybe erroneously, that this other kind of anger is really a type of knowledge: the type that both clarifies and disappoints. It responds to insult and attempted erasure simply by asserting presence, and the energy required to present, to react, to assert is accompanied by visceral disappointment: a disappointment in the sense that no amount of visibility will alter the ways in which one is perceived. (*@Rankine2014*, pp. 31-32)

/consumerism-often-relies-on-white-fasci.content:
# consumerism often relies on white fascination with Black bodies

White fascination with Black bodies and culture stems from the history of blackface minstrelsy, which was one of Americaâ€™s first widely-popular entertainment forms (*@BlueV2017*). 

This history continues today in the use of Black bodies and culture to market products (the consumers of which are always unmarked and thus considered white by default).

/consumers-want-to-feel-victorious.content:
# consumers want to feel victorious

A claim from *@BlueV2017* who considers the use of Black resistance as a marketing tactic. Since [neutral and unmarked subjects are always signified as white](neutral%20and%20unmarked%20subjects%20are%20always%20signified%20as%20white.md), this demonstrates how Black resistance is appropriated by white consumers who project themselves into the victory of *resistance*.  Also suggests how *affect is used in consumerism*.

/noise-is-a-form-of-othered-sound.content:
# noise is a form of othered sound

*!Mack Hagood*, as cited in *@BlueV2017*, explores the problematization of noise as an impact of *individualism* in the *neoliberal* era, where sounds which are not personally chosen become constructed as the noise of the other.

The transformation of women's conversation from sound to chattering noise, for example, demonstrates the way that [sound is always filtered through aspects of human subjectivity](sound%20is%20always%20filtered%20through%20aspects%20of%20human%20subjectivity.md).

/resistance-vs-existence.title: resistance vs existence
/resistance-vs-existence.content:
# resistance vs existence

*@BlueV2017* argues that if Black subjects are considered disadvantaged, disempowered, and oppressed, all forms of Black innovation necessarily become understood through a lens of *resistance*. 

Through *!Stephanie Leigh Batiste*, he argues that this can be a limiting *narrative* as it constructs Blackness through its oppositional relation to white supremacy. It also implies that Black people are have no agency or empowerment and ignores the ways that Black people can become complicit or invested in imperialist power structures. 

 > 
 > Black people are not always already resistant, though they descend from a legacy of oppression that still haunts everyday life in the United States. (*@BlueV2017*, p. 100)

 > 
 > Black people possess agency, and it is naiÌˆve to assume that all decisions are resistant in nature; in fact, some decisions are made with full intent to participate in dominant culture. This is not to say that black people are not oppressed and not disempowered, but to say that those forces do not remove the possibility of imagining and enacting oneself as empowered.(*@BlueV2017*, p. 101)

 > 
 > They are existing, not always resisting, and it is naiÌˆve (and racist) to assume that there cannot be space for their own articulations of self and identity. (*@BlueV2017*, p. 103)

To add more nuance to Black innovation and make room for Black agency, Blue considers a *self-possessed* Black existence through quietness, suggesting resistance as an active and loud activity, while existence rests on quietness and interiority.

/sound-is-political.content:
# sound is political

*@BlueV2017* shoes two ways that power rests with those who control sound:

1. who gets to make what sounds where is determined by social norms and legislation (see also the way that [sound is always filtered through aspects of human subjectivity](sound%20is%20always%20filtered%20through%20aspects%20of%20human%20subjectivity.md) and how [noise is a form of othered sound](noise%20is%20a%20form%20of%20othered%20sound.md))
1. forms of authority use sound as a weapon, deterrent, and announcement of authority

The politics of sound are embedded in a *individualist* philosophy which positions sound as against peace and individual rights. *!Jonathan Sterne* describes the development of this politics as an [audile technique](audile%20technique.md).
